the cool temperatures of spring are finally behind
us and I for one am eagerly anticipating the

chance to enjoy Canada at its finest during the
upcoming summer months. With the end of school for
many, June often seems to disappear in the blink of an eye,
so I would encourage all of you to make your plans now
and book your visit to the Numismatic event of the year  
the RCNA s 63 Annual Convention and  Canada s Money
Collector Show  being held this year in Ottawa from Tuesday,
July 19, to Sunday, July 24. You might even consider
planning your family s vacation to take in many of the
sights the Ottawa region has to offer. The natural beauty
around Canada s capital is spectacular during the summer.

To ensure a good time for all, the Convention
Committee of the Ottawa Numismatic Society is busily
working on features for your pleasure. Although some
of the details remain in flux, events and tours have been
scheduled in between the many numismatic activities that
will appeal to all attendees. The RCNA has been advised
by the Royal Canadian Mint that its traditional Thursday
evening annual reception, at our convention over the last
forty years, will not be held this year because of policy
changes affecting every Crown Corporation s ability to
host social events. However, the RCM has assured us that
it will still be a strong presence at the Convention, and
it is currently finalizing its activities to take place on the
bourse, including the opportunity for Convention visitors
to meet coin designers and engravers in person.

It gives me great pleasure to announce that we have
appointed Kevin Day-Thorburn, the Association s
Director for New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island,
as the editor of our electronic bulletin Wi ores. Kevin
has a great deal of experience producing newsletters, and
we are expecting great things from him. I would like to
thank all those members who had volunteered for the
position.

I would also like to thank Judy Blackman for her
service as the interim-editor. Judy had jumped to our
rescue, on very short notice, when our previous editor
was unable to continue. It is very encouraging to me
when our members volunteer their precious time to help
our Association move forward.

In closing, for those planning to attend our
Convention please make your reservation right away.
The Convention hotel, the Delta Ottawa City Centre, is
selling out quickly!

Rob Turner began collecting
Canadian decimal coinage
as a teenager growing up in
Maine during the 1960s. By
1980, he had focused his
passion upon collecting and
studying Victorian cents.
During the last thirty years,
he has assembled multiple
sets of these fascinating
coins, including a mint state
set containing all of the date
and obverse variety combinations.

Since 2007, Rob has authored four highly acclaimed
books and several articles on Victorian cent die varieties.
In addition to describing in detail how the Royal Mint
manufactured these coins, his books include comprehensive
die catalogs for the dates 1858, 1859 over 1858, 1890-H,
1891, and 1892. His work on this series continues.

Rob has been elected as a Fellow of the Canadian Numismatic
Research Society. He currently serves as Vice President of that

Numismatic Research for his book, Dies and Diadems. He holds
membership in both the Royal Canadian Numismatic Association
and the American Numismatic Association. He serves as

Canadian numismatic editors and writers unite

The 2016 RCNA convention will be hosting the inaugural
meeting of the Canadian Association of Numismatic
Editors and Writers (CANEW).

All Canadian numismatic writers and editors are invited
to join this new association, whose aim is to promote
numismatic writing through the sharing of tips, tools,
information, and education on research, writing, editing, and
publishing (and this provided in both official languages).

Behind this endeavour is the editorial team that worked
on moneta, the Ottawa Numismatic Society publication
that won  Best in Canada  and  Best in North America 
three times in its four-year lifespan: Ron Cheek, Wilfred
Lauber, Serge Pelletier, and Steve Woodland.

There are so many accessible tools out there that
are very useful to both writers and editors,  said Serge
Pelletier,  we just want to make sure that everyone knows
about them.

We re also inviting those who would like to become
writers,  said Steve Woodland.
Hudson s Bay Company Collectors Society

Please join fellow Hudson s Bay Company collectors and
enthusiasts on Friday July 22, 2016, for our inaugural
meeting during the 2016 RCNA Convention at the Delta
Ottawa City Centre Hotel. We will be meeting from 2:00 p.m.
to 3:00 p.m. in the Chaudi re room. All interested parties are
welcome!

Larry Gingras  monumental catalogue has long served as
the most significant text for fur trade exonumia. This includes
items such as tokens, medals, and scrip. Since its publication,
it has become difficult to find and so, prohibitively expensive.
Genuine numismatic discoveries have been made in the more
than four decades since its publication. As well, a plethora of
forgeries and fantasies have come to light during the Internet
age. Share your experiences to help make a progressive and
stimulating improvement to one of Canada s most fascinating
and under-researched areas of numismatics. Chief among this
organization s goals will be updating the reference material
for both novice and seasoned collector.

Our first meeting will feature a short presentation on
the Hudson s Bay Company in Norway House Manitoba;
one of the most important fur trade posts on the route
towards Churchill and the company s namesake body
of water. Never-before-seen photos and artifacts will
be presented. The remainder of the meeting will allow
those present to speak about what they desire from such
an organization and where we should move forward in
structure, purpose, and direction.

85. The Tale of a Long Lost Temple (known only from coins)

the three coins illustrated span all that is
| known of an important temple in the
Roman Forum. Exactly where it
was and what eventually happened to it
are lost to history.

This is the Temple of Divus Augustus
and Diva Augusta (Livia). It is first
portrayed on the sestertius (top right)
issued in A.D. 39 to commemorate its
opening in 37 by Catus (Caligula) early
in his reign before the onset of what may
have been schizophrenia. The seated figure
of Pietas on the obverse is in commemoration of
the emperor s looking after the deification of his
imperial great-grandfather, Augustus (although
the temple had been begun in the reign of
Tiberius (14-37). On the left of the temple
we can see DIVO while opposite on the right
the word AVG is lost in a bit of patina and
some corrosion. (Of course Augustus died in
14, Livia not until 29 so it must have been in
the works for a while since the temple, eight years
after her death, was dedicated only to Augustus).
Caligula stands in front of the new temple s

six columned fa ade (termed hexastyle). A
ceremonial floral garland hangs from the
pediment and its ends hang down beside the
last columns, all of whose capitals are in the

very elegant Ionic order. The figures in the
pediment have been identified from a variety of
specimens and include the founding figures of Aeneas
and Anchises as well as Augustus himself seen here as
the tall figure presiding over the centre. Around Caligula
(whose toga has been drawn up to cover his head as was
customary at religious services) are several acolytes
passing him the required objects. This is a victimless
sacrifice, and probably involved wine or some other
precious substance. Beside the emperor s right knee is a
low altar.

The centre coin jumps us ahead 120 years. It is the
reverse of an As of the emperor Antoninus Pius (138-161)
minted at Rome in 159. Around the edge is the inscription
AEDE DIVI AVG REST SC COS III. This means
that the temple of Divus Augustus was restored late in
Antoninus s reign. The coin s reverse shows Augustus
still standing in the centre of the building s pediment.
Number 4
June 2016
There are the reclining figures in the corners
(acroteria) as before. Below them however
are now eight columns (called octastyle).
This is corroborated in the bottom
coin s reverse, a dupondius this time,
which represented two Ases or half a
sestertius. The reverse inscription is
TEMPLVM DIVI AVG REST SC
COS ITI. (Aede and Templum are
alternative words for  temple  although
there are shades of meaning differences).
The same figures adorn the pediment, but
once again there are eight columns and this time
it can be seen that the simple Ionic capitals have
been replaced by ornate Corinthians. Note
the pair of statues representing the imperial
couple raised up to show perspective inside
the building. Antoninus s restoration must
have been more of a complete rebuilding job.
Our only clue to the location of this temple
since absolutely none of it has survived lies in
a comment by Caligula himself reported by the
historian Suetonius. In his later regnal years
as his mental health deteriorated he began
to see himself on a par with the gods. He
even managed to imagine a conference with
Jupiter, his father, who resided in his Temple
atop the Palatine Hill. This lay on the other
side of a small valley from the imperial palace.
He imagined constructing a walkway from that
palace to the roof of the Temple of Divus Augustus and

thence straight to the Temple of Jupiter, so it must have
lain in that valley.

In 80, during the reign of Titus a great fire ravaged the
Temple of Jupiter and spread to the Forum (see Nummus
Matrices #35 and #75). This fire must have seriously
damaged the Temple of Divus Augustus and Diva Augusta
as well as much of the rest of the Forum including the
mint and with everything in ruins this temple had to wait
its turn, a turn that took 79 years in coming.

Much of this is unrecorded or hasn t survived. It is
numismatics that fills in the blanks to tell the whole story.

Canada 50 cents Severe Die Deterioration Doubling

this month s column features a coin that
| 1s quite fascinating, yet has remained
relatively under the radar for more

than 40 years. Specifically, the coin I am
referring to is the 1969 50 cents with
severe die deterioration doubling on the
entire obverse devices, most noticeably
on the effigy.

Die deterioration doubling, otherwise
known as  die fatigue  (Stanton, 2004), is
often confused with resultant effects from a
punch-doubled die. As the die deteriorates, the
devices will develop secondary images created
when their edges are broken down by stresses
on the metal. This doubling tends to radiate
out from the centre of the die to the edge.
Often, at the far outer edges of dies that
are deteriorating, the die s denticles
and fields can create an  orange-peel 
effect on the surfaces of the struck coin,
rather than sharp smooth struck surfaces.
Die fatigue can result when the Royal
Canadian Mint tries to get the maximum
production out of its dies.

On the obverse of the 1969 50 cents,
the doubling is possibly a combination
of die deterioration and over polishing. Doubling is observed
radiating outward from the centre of the effigy creating a
doubled image, a border-like effect, around the Queen (Figure
2, p 183). Only the edges of the devices that are touching the
fields are doubled; other features inside the devices, such as
the Queen s crown, hair, ear, etc., are not doubled (Figure 2A,
2B). Forbes and Zoell (1970) reported a similar phenomenon
occurring on the 1968 50-cent strikes (Zoell # V470a, p. 45),

in their last Canadian variety volume, attributing
it to  Filling in around Queen due to over
resurfacing.  This is by no means a new
discovery; some sharp-eyed collectors

have noticed this severe doubling on the
1969 50 cents and reported it on Internet
coin forums, Numicanada (2008) and
Com Community Family (2014).

Collecting die deterioration doubling
strikes 1s somewhat less popular than
machine doubling strikes and certainly
much less common than punch (hub) doubled
varieties. The most popular Canadian die
deterioration doubling strikes are the 1962
doubled-date variants in the 1-cent and
5-cent strikes and the 1979 1-cent doubled
date. The 1969 50 cents deteriorated die
should be fairly easy to spot in the wild,
so grab your loupe and keep up the hunt!

Number Tumbler Trouble
this month s error is certainly different from any
we have ever discussed in an Oops column before.

This month we will talk about an interesting error
which can occur in paper money.

The error in question is on some Canadian $1.00 notes
from the 1954  Canadian Landscape Series  first issued that
September. Our example notes are actually from the Modified
Portrait variety issued later, in 1956. The astute observer will
immediately notice the error in each of our two example notes
to the right. The notes have single-digit mismatched serial
numbers! The second digit in the left serial number is 6 while
the second digit in the right serial number is 7. Examples
of multiple-digit mismatches are known to exist but are
significantly more rare than one-digit mismatches, however
all are very hard to find.

Before we examine the cause of the error let us take a
step back to introduce this series of
banknotes.

With the death of King George VI
in 1952 the Bank of Canada prepared
to issue its third series of notes. When
designs submitted by the Canadian
Bank Note Company were deemed
to be too close to the previous 1937
series of notes, the Bank of Canada
contracted with the famous artist
Charles Fraser Comfort to  develop
a more contemporary design for
Canada $ currency.  In the end images
of Canadian rural landscapes were
chosen for the backs of the notes.
The portrait, now at the right

sides on the notes, was based on a
photograph of Queen Elizabeth IT
by Canadian photographer Yousuf
Karsh. This portrait appeared on all
denominations from $1 to $1,000.
The master image of the portrait
was engraved by George Gunderson
of the British American Bank Note
Company. This original portrait was
modified slightly in 1956 after the
famous  Devil s Face  controversy
resulting in two varieties of this series
of notes.

The Modified Portrait 1954 series of banknotes
followed a slightly different procedure for printing and
numbering notes than that used for the previous 1937
series. The 1937 series, as did the original 1954 Devils
Face Portrait notes, was printed 24-notes per sheet, while
starting in 1956 notes were printed 32-notes per sheet.
This continued until 1968, when they began to be printed
as 40-notes per sheet. In all cases, the notes were printed
in a skip-numbered fashion so that sheets, when stacked,
could be cut into bricks, or bundles with 500 or 1,000
consecutively-numbered notes.

The seven-digit serial numbers were preceded by a two
prefix letters, configured as a fraction. The upper letter was
the series letter and the lower letter was the denominational
letter. For each denominational letter there were twenty-
five series letters, the letter Q was not used.
The CN Journal Volume 61

The manufacture of banknotes is a complex multi-
stage printing process. For the 1954 series, the process
had been streamlined by using only one intaglio plate
instead of two and two lithographic plates followed by
two letterpress stages. Each one of the plates carries only
a portion of the finished design. These banknotes were
printed on dry substrate, paper consisting of 50 percent
flax and 50 percent cotton, rather than using the wet paper
printing process used previously.

The intaglio plate, in which the lines to be printed
are cut into a metal plate, is responsible for creating
the raised tactile-ink distinctive to engraved banknotes.
These engraved incuse lines hold the special ink to be
transferred to the paper when it is squeezed into the plate
under pressure.

With the lithographic printing plates it is the raised
surfaces of the metal plate that transfer the ink to the
paper. This process is used to apply the colour and tones
to the front and back of the note.

After the sheets are printed and dried the serial numbers
are added to each sheet using a complex letterpress with

64 rollers (two per note position on the sheet) configured
with a 7-tumbler system that automatically advances its
count after each cycle, to prepare for the next sheet.

It is at this stage that the error made on our two example
notes occurred. It appears that one of these roller pairs
was out of sync   either it was setup that way or failed to
advance at sometime during the print run.

You might ask,  How can you narrow it down to a
problem with only one roller pair?  Well the answer is that
we don t really know for sure how many positions might
have been effected, but what we do know is that it appears
that these two notes came from the same position on different
sheets. In fact they would have come from the same brick
of notes. We know this because the serial numbers of the
two notes vary only in the last three digits, being only 210
note positions apart; and that in both cases the numbers are
below 500. Since the sheets are skip-numbered so that 500 or
1,000 sheets can be stacked on top of each other and then the
stack cut into (in our case) 32 bricks, each brick containing
consecutively numbered notes, the notes from different
bricks would need to be at least 500 numbers apart.

We can also speculate that because
of this, and assuming that the error was
not discovered on other sheets, that
there might be as many as 500 or more
of these mismatched serial number
notes. The series would all start with
A/O 0683xxx on the left and, of course,
A/O 0783xxx on the right. If you aware
of other examples from this serial
number series please contact the author
at fenix@rogers.com .

At this time the final step in the
production of the banknotes was
the addition of the signatures of the
Governor and the Deputy-Governor
of the Bank of Canada. This last
step was performed by the Bank
itself using a letterpress, until 1965
when it authorized the engraving of
signatures directly onto the intaglio
plates.

Canadian banknote errors are an
interesting area that appeals to both
the error collector and the general
paper-money enthusiast. The notes
always carry strong premiums
whenever they appear in auction or
for sale by private treaty.
As always, keep your eyes open!

cent coin. Sometimes it s in a clear
plastic pouch, brittle with age, but
usually the coin is taped to the cover
without protection, save a layer of
lacquer that was applied to it soon
after it was struck. The lacquer,
where it was not damaged by years
of contact with the tape, protected
the coin s original bright red color,
making it easy to see its strong
cameo effect. In fact, the cents
found on these postcard sets are
specimen strikes.

maple leaf (struck in 1948) and

2015 Review of the Activities of
The J. Douglas Ferguson Historical Research Foundation

A very productive annual meeting of the Foundation was
held during the 2015 RCNA Convention in Halifax in July.
The meeting began with a moment of silence for Rev. Dr.
Bernard O Connor who passed away on May 10, 2015.
Because of Rev. O Connor s generous donation the
Foundation is able to endow graduate scholarships in his
name to four Canadian universities. Laval University has
had the greatest success in finding a well-qualified recipient
for each year of the first three years the scholarship has
been offered. Carleton University, the University of British
Columbia, and Memorial University have had varying
success, with the scholarship not awarded in every year.
They will continue to make every effort to give out the
award from accumulated funds.
The following business items are of note:

An Executive Committee of the Board was struck
comprising the Chair, Deputy Chair, immediate
ex-Chair, Secretary, Treasurer, and the Chair of the
Investment Committee. The Executive Committee
was struck to deal with items of business which arise
between annual meetings. It met for the first time
during Toronto Coin Expo in October, 2015.

Graham Esler, Chair of the Publications Committee,
provided an update on various book projects
in the works. One of the projects is the Chair s
book on the Upper Canada Coppers, 1815-1841,
which has been completed and sent to Spink in
August for publication in the New Year. There was
also agreement in principle that we look into the
possibility of publishing Volume IT of Adam Shortt s
Nova Scotia papers, which was originally planned as
the Foundation s first publication. These papers were
deposited with the Bank of Canada. It is hoped that
manuscripts of additional projects will be completed
in the near future and that the Foundation can support
their publication.

An initiative to digitally scan Eugene Courteau s

monographs on Canadian tokens was also approved
by the Executive Committee. The digitized
monographs will be made freely available to
all collectors on the Internet via a link at the
Foundation s Web site. Paul Petch has agreed to
attend to the technical aspects of this initiative.
There were several changes to Board positions in

2015. Robert Forbes was named Deputy Chair of
the Board in place of Paul Johnson, who wished to
retire from the position given the pressures of other
demands. Effective August 15, 2015, Neil Probert
officially took over from Len Buth as Treasurer of
the Foundation. It was confirmed that effective April
1, 2016, Scott Douglas will replace Rick Craig as
Chair of our Investment Committee. We extend our
thanks to Len and Rick for so ably performing their
duties for so many years.
A request for funding was received from the co-

chairs of the 2016 RCNA Convention in support of a
 Numicamp  for young collectors immediately prior
to the Convention. This request was circulated to
the Board in Halifax. Subsequently, the Executive
Committee supported the goals of the Numicamp
initiative and agreed to help fund the educational
portion using a staged approach to a maximum of
$2500 if the enrollment limit of 20 participants is
achieved.

FRENCH COINAGE SPECIFICALLY FOR
COLONIAL AMERICA
the Colonial Coin Collectors Club, C4, released
Sydney F. Martin s latest book, French Coinage
Specifically For Colonial America. This is the third
colonial com book written by Syd Martin. The other works are
now considered standard references and Syd s long awaited

new book is expected to become the leading reference works
on French Coinage minted for circulation in North America.

According to Lou Jordan, the curator of numismatic
collections for the University of Notre Dame,  Syd Martin
has written the definitive catalogue of French coinage
authorized specifically for use in North America.  Jordan
went on to state that  this is an essential book for anyone
interested in the French coinage of colonial North America.

What many early American coin collectors fail to
recognize,  Martin said upon the book s release,  is that from
the 16  century until 1763, New France included much of what
is now the United States, as well as most of Canada. As such,
coins minted by France for circulation in its North American
colonies should be considered  coins of the realm  in these
areas.  Colonial numismatic expert, John Kraljevich, went on
to explain that  the history of the French in what is today the
United States is largely forgotten. However, the memory of these
people and their coinage has been long cherished in Canada.

Jim Rosen, president of C4, predicts that  Martin's new
book will awaken an interest in both the history of the
French speaking people in North American and the coins
they used such as the Gloriam Regni coins of 1670, the 6-
and 12-denier copper coins minted in 1717, and the copper
9-denier coins from 1721 and 1722, all of which were struck
in France specifically for circulation in the Americas.

In the book s introduction, John Kraljevich writes that,
 With Crosby-like flair, Syd has marshaled together the
original documents that tell the stories of these coinages.
Most have never been published at all, let alone in English
or all in one place. This original research guarantees this
works importance to researchers in every forthcoming
generation. The heart of this book, the die studies, offers
several pathways for collectors to navigate these series,
by basic type, by major variety, by die combination, or
even by die state. It s a project that no one has ever even
attempted before, an outlier in the world of colonial
numismatics, a field that has seen multiple die studies of
most of the popular series. Given Syd's well-organized
approach and the thousands of coins he s studied, it may
be generations before this work is supplanted. It s doubtful
anyone will ever do it any better.
